Executive Summary

EPA Risk Management Plan - Resubmit

Schoep's Ice Cream Company, Inc. - Madison, WI 53704

Revised 7/12/19





EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Schoep's Ice Cream Division Street Facility complies with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations. All employees are informed of hazards in the workplace. Employees who work with potentially hazardous substances receive proper training in the handling of those substances. This facility has procedures in place to safely remove employees from areas in the unlikely event that a hazardous substance release were to occur, and to put in place emergency notification and action procedures.



2. Facility and Regulated Substances

Schoep's Ice Cream Company, Inc. process Ice Cream Products.  The facility utilizes Anhydrous Ammonia as a refrigerant to maintain the proper temperatures of Milk, Cream, and Ice Cream at 514 Division Street Madison, WI 53704.  Ammonia, a gas at normal atmospheric temperature and pressure, is used in an anhydrous form liquefied under pressure in a two stage process.  The refrigeration system consists of a High Pressure Receiver, Evaporators, Compressors, Condensers, Vessels, Piping and numerous types of Valves.  Schoep's Ice Cream, Division Street Facility has an integrated safety management program to prevent ammonia releases and mitigate the consequences of a release, should one occur.



3. Worst Case and Alternative Case Release Scenarios

Off Site Consequence (OCA) data is available for review onsite at the Schoep's Ice Cream facility.



4. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Ammonia Specific Prevention

The Schoep's Ice Cream, Madison, WI - Division Street Facility has an emergency plan that addresses the actions necessary in the event of a release of ammonia from the refrigeration system. Because of the pungent odor of ammonia, any leak is easily detected. The compressor rooms are provided with ammon

ia detectors and visual alarms. The refrigeration system is designed so that major components can be isolated by closing selected valves. Further, refrigeration system operators and contractors have been trained and are knowledgeable in the safe operation of the refrigeration system.    In case of a release that could travel off the plant property, calls would be made to the Madison Fire Department and the appropriate agencies to assist in the response. Other state and federal notifications would be made as required.



5. Five Year Accident History

There has not been a release of hazardous substance from the covered process within the pasts five years which resulted in death, injury, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.



6. Emergency Response Program

This storage facility has procedures in place to react in the event of a release of a hazardous substance. Employees are trained to evacuate their respective areas in accordance with OSHA 1910.38(a). Coordination with the Dane County Emergency Management/LEPC, the Madison  Fire Department, and others is initiated during an emergency situation.



7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Schoep's Ice Cream, Division Street Facility expects to improve safety performance by emphasizing all elements of its' PSM/RMP program.  All recommendations during the most recent Process Hazard Analysis and PSM Compliance Audit were designed to improve the safety performance of the ammonia refrigeration process.  Schoep's Ice Cream expects to evaluate each recommendation in a timely manner and implement, as soon as possible, those recommendations that will reduce the possibility of a release and/or mitigate the consequences of an unintentional release.



Continual improvement and innovation:  

In addition to complying with EPA and OSHA regulations and standards, Schoep's Ice Cream Co. has worked closely with the Industrial R

efrigeration Consortium (IRC) located at the University of Wisconsin in order to promote knowledge and information sharing in the field of industrial refrigeration, further ensuring the safety of our personnel, the community and the surrounding environment.  It is our goal to continuously improve safety at our facility by carefully monitoring our refrigeration and other systems and procedures in order to identify any opportunity for improvement.
